p.s: After dealing with the content of the argument between Macbeth and his wife it is neccessary to analyse how Lady Macbeth tries to persuade her husband.
In my analysis I am going to focus on her choice of language, including stylistic devices.
One aspect that becomes obvious while just looking at the excerpt is that Lady Macbeth speaks much more than her husband.
This could already be a technique of her'sher for trying to make Macbeth speechless and overwhelmed.

After he tries to convince her to not committing the murder by using noble words like golden (l. 4) and gloss (l. 5) to describe the good opinions from many, maybe important, people, she uses the metaphor [...]the hope [...] [w]herein you dressed yourself (l. 8-9).

With this stylistic device she refers to clothes you put on everyday to show her husband that he changes his mind as quickly and frequently as he changes his clothes and to make him think and feel bad about this.
She also personificates the hope (l. 9-11) to show Macbeth how disappointed she is about the fact that the motivation he had some time ago fell asleep.
By relating his mixed feelings about the plan to his love for her (l. 11-12) she wants to make him insecure and emotional in order to convince him more easily afterwards.
She questions and insults his masculinity by asking him if he was not strong enough to fight for what he is wishing for (l. 12ff.) and even calls him a coward (l. 16).

This must be really hurtful and insulting for him because he is a brave fighter and Lady Macbeth probably knows that she has to say things like these to make him angry and to make him want to prove her wrong.

When the ruthless lady calls the crown the ornament of life (l. 15) she wants to make her husband realise that becoming king is the only important thing in his life and that nothing should keep him from fighting for his (in thine own esteem (l. 16)) dream.
By saying Letting I dare not wait upon I would (l. 17) Lady Macbeth portrays him as a weak lazy person and as someone who will not do anything to get what he wants.
This attacks his pride and makes him even more insecure and submissive which helps her with her intention of persuading him of killing the current king.

The simile and question Like the poor cat i'th adage? (l. 18) should also make him feel bad because of the comparison with a sweet, weak animal and should make him want to prove that he is very masculine.
Macbeth's try to defend himself with an antithesis (l. 21-22) is not very convincing and seems a bisbit desperate.
His wife knows about this and continues to question his manhood by saying that the only way to be man again is to say I dare again.
In this context she repeats the word man (l. 26, l. 28).
The whole conversation is about her making him feel weak and by repeating this word she supports the effect of her statements on her husband.
Lady Macbeth then wants to make Macbeth realise how little sense his change of mind makes by saying that the now existing fitness [of] time [and] place [...] [d]oes unmake [him] (l. 28-31).
Macbeth probably knows about this but hearing it from a beloved person might make him insecure in his opinion and thus easier to persuade.
After that she gives an extreme, brutal example of killing her own child if she had [...] sworn as [he has] done to this (l. 35-36).
Here she uses phrases like plucked my nipple (l. 34) and dashed the brains out (l. 35) that probably shock her husband.

The fact that she has given suck (l. 31) shows that the two of them could have had a child which maybe died and confronting him with this dark past is a ruthless but good technique to make him shocked and submissive.
The example should also show him how far she would go to keep a promise she made to him and how disappointed she is about him not thinking the same way.
Macbeth's question (l. 39) shows that he already is very insecure and partly convinced and the answer of his wife (l. 39) should tell him that even a failure would not be that bad.
She is using the imperative (l. 40-41) to clarify that he is the one who can prevent them from failing and to show him that she is really angry about his doubts.
By using a parenthesis from line 41 to 43 she gives Macbeth extra information about the plan that should take his last doubts away and show him that everything will work out.

Using the hyperbalion Will I with wine and wassail so convince [...] (l. 44f.) and the imagery of the memory as warder of the brain (l. 45) she illustrates that if she makes the guards drunk and deletes their memory, everyone will suspect them and they will not even know if they are innocent or not themselves.
This should make her husband more confident regarding the plan.
Also the imagery that the memory disappears through the limback (brain) shows that the guard'sguards' brains will not be able to hold on to any memory.
Lady Macbeth uses the phrase swinish sleep (l. 48) to make Macbeth associate the guards with pigs which might make it easier for him to put the blame on them.

Her rhetorical questions at the end (ll. 50-53) and the use of the word great (l. 53) to describe the crime might also assure her husband that there is nothing to worry about and thus lead to a more convincing end.

Macbeth's last words show that he is shocked and surprised about his wife's attitude but he seems convinced and talks about the strong gender again (l. 55-57) which was very important throughout the whole argument.
Generally Lady Macbeth uses long, hypotactic sentences (l. 31ff.) and many questions (l. 9ff., l. 24f.) to make Macbeth speechless and think about his bad decision.
Her tone and choice of words are often slightly agressiveaggressive (l. 35) what should make her husband shocked and submissive.
All in all one can say that Lady Macbeth uses many techniques and stylistic devices to make Macbeth speechless.
She knows her husband very well and says the right things to get him to agree with her.
